title.narrative: Towards A Hlp Based Methodology For Stabilizing And Creating Conditions For Peace In Countries Affected By The Syria Crisis

description.narrative:
Overall goal: The HLP rights of populations affected by the Syrian crisis are promoted and achieved through shared relevant information to refugees, enhanced capacities of municipalities, and developed HLP knowledge of both refugees and landlords.This goal will be accomplished by achieving the following objectives:Objective-1: Linkages between HLP issues and future return of refugees to their homelands are assessed and analyzed. This involves examining relevant legal HLP documents available with the refugees, as well as identifying the current status of housing and tenure in refugees' areas of origin. Objective-2: Shelter conditions for refugees are enhanced and forced evictions are decreased through properly shared HLP information and enhanced capacities at the municipality, community, and refugees levels;Activities:Achieving Objective-1 involves undertaking a rapid assessment of the current ownership and tenure rights of refugee communities from Syria, and a detailed study of property state, legal documentation and tenure rights in case and/or to motivate return to Syria once the conflict has ceased. In order to get a full understanding of the situation within a reasonable timeframe, the assessment will target refugee families coming from the same region in Syria. It is likely that a sample of 250 refugee families who were displaced from Homs and its vicinity, and residing in different areas over Lebanon, will be part of the research on HLP documentations. Taking into account the devastating amount of destruction in Syria due to the war, the survey will also look into the state of the owned properties in refugees' homeland, which remains unknown and requires further research. Under Objective 1, the following activities will be undertaken:Develop the research tools: This will involve a multi-sectoral questionnaire that will be used during the interviews with refugee households. The questionnaire will mainly look into HLP legal documents that the refugees still possess or not, and the implication of that when returning back to their homelands. In addition, the questionnaire will seek to understand if other issues rather than the HLP issues may also affect the return of families. This may include health and education services, security and safety, and basic urban services. In full collaboration with UNHCR, identify the sample-families who will be interviewed. This will require review of refugee files to identify the 250 cases coming from Homs region. Conduct the research through household visits to the identified refugee families. The study will involve a wide variety of cases to be assessed; people whose houses were totally or partially destroyed, others whose lands and properties were occupied or confiscated, areas were basic and social services are absent or partially exist, etc. The research will be conducted in partnership with UNHCR. This will also contribute to ensuring confidentiality of gathered data. Analyze gathered information, identify gaps and challenges related to the assessed sectors; HLP, health, education, security, basic services, etc. Develop a checklist of issues and queries that need to be checked out and identified at the level of the areas of origin of targeted refugees/beneficiaries. Based on the developed checklist, conduct the field work in the areas of origin of the interviewed refugees, to understand the current situation of housing, tenure, and services in Homs region. This will be done through UN-Habitat Syria Programme office through their field partners; mainly local/national NGOs. The current security situation in the Governorate of Homs will allow for such work to be carried out.Organize a national workshop involving concerned partners to discuss the findings of the research and to agree on a set of recommendations and measures to ensure refugees HLP rights upon their return to their homeland.Publish and disseminate the final report of the research.Objective-2 involves a wide range of activities targeting refugees, local authorities, owners of housing units or lands, and local communities. As most of HLP issues and forced evictions are reported to be happening within the urban extensions of the cities, the proposed activities under Objective-2 will be piloted in Bourj Hammoud, one of the highly dense areas within the Eastern suburbs of Beirut. Bourj Hammoud is inhabited by a variety of nationalities; Initially, Armenian refugees were the majority of the residents. However, the area attracted foreign workers, mainly from Syria, Ethiopia and Sri Lanka due to affordable renting prices and availability of cheap-labor jobs and informal work. Before the crisis, the population of Bourj Hammoud was estimated at 75,000 residents, with poverty levels in 2004 reaching 8,500 people with income under 4$ a day. With the outbreak of the Syrian war, some 18,500 Syrian refugees sought refuge in the area. This massive influx of Syrian refugees came to add more strain on the neighborhood, which is already highly congested, and challenged by a number of environmental as well as socio-economic problems.Due to the presence of a large number of refugees who are mostly either renting single rooms or sharing small apartments, conflicts with owners of shelter options which frequently lead to forced evictions are being repeatedly reported. Refugees enter into rental agreements verbally without any legal papers and without knowing their rights and responsibilities. The same happens with owners who look for quick easy profit without taking into account the legal aspects. Moreover, inhabitants poorly know about HLP issues and they always put the blame on refugees for any occurring conflict. The Project promotes the establishment of a Reference Information Center within Bourj Hammoud which will be likely hosted by a local NGO The center will provide legal advice, raise public awareness on HLP rights, and enhance the capacities of local authorities on HLP issues. While municipalities and their personnel will have their knowledge on HLP legal issues developed, owners and refugees will be thoroughly informed and advised on their rights and responsibilities. 5,000 Refugee household, 2,000 vulnerable Lebanese population, and 500 owners of shelter options within the targeted area will benefit from the services of the Info Center. Under Objective 2, the following activities will be implemented: Establishing Info Centers (IC) within the targeted areas: ICs aim to create local systems that will reduce forced evictions through enhanced commitment of municipalities towards HLP issues, and through improved local knowledge and practices related to HLP issues including legal frameworks and rights on rental and contractual procedures and arrangements. The IC will be established as part of a local NGO structure within the targeted area, and will include a Legal Advisor (LA) and a Social worker (SW) who will be reaching out mayors, refugees and owners within the different communities. The LA and the SW will closely coordinate with UNHCR field officers and outreach teams and will also liaise with NRC to ensure synergies avoid overlapping of activities.
The key functions of the ICs are:
Understand HLP issues and practices present within the targeted areas, and identify key challenges at the level of the refugees, host population and local authorities; Provide relevant services related to HLP. This involves promoting formal lease agreements that will reduce forced evictions. Raise public awareness on HLP issues: this will involve the development of materials that will be shared with targeted groups through AR campaigns. Establish info-sharing and referral mechanisms involving all concerned actors: UN-Habitat will ensure a close coordination between the IC and UNHCR field officers, ICLA/NRC, and other concerned agencies operating in the targeted areas.Awareness Raising: One of the key functions of the IC will be to increase local awareness on HLP issues and legal rights on rental and contractual procedures and arrangements. The campaigns will target different beneficiary groups; unions and municipalities, owners and refugees, SDCs and local NGOs, etc.
Legal advice: The Legal Advisor is expected to provide legal advice on rental and contractual procedures. In addition, potential cases that require different type of legal intervention or referral to appropriate actors, such as evictions, poor shelter conditions and SGVB will be also provided.
